newsitem.title: CHINA: HK people back Tung's housing reform policy - poll.
newsitem.headline: HK people back Tung's housing reform policy - poll.

text.p: New leader Tung Chee-hwa has won the support of more than half Hong Kong citizens for his housing reform drive to beat skyrocketing residential prices, a poll said on Wednesday.
The survey yielded the first public reaction to an inaugural policy speech by the new post-colonial leader of China's latest and richest Special Region.

Respondents said they believed his 10-year plan unveiled on Tuesday, first day of Beijing's Hong Kong rule, would stabilise home prices in this crowded region where the government controls the supply of land for building.

Tung said he would act to curb property speculation. He promised efforts to increase land supply and housing production, saying he planned a 70 per cent home ownership rate in a decade for this territory of 6.4 million people.

Dismaying prospective homebuyers, Hong Kong residential prices have soared almost 30 percent this year on speculation and land scarcity in a region with some of the world's most expensive property values.
Hong Kong, a former British colony, returned to Chinese rule at midnight on Monday when Beijing-backed Tung became new leader.
About 56 percent of 1,600 people surveyed by a property agency on Tuesday and published in Ming Pao Daily newspaper on Wednesday, said they thought Tung's housing policy could stabilise prices.
In the poll, 65 per cent of respondents said increasing the supply of land on the market was the most effective solution to Hong Kong's housing problem.
More than 60 percent of respondents said they had confidence in Hong Kong's economic development, usually sensitive to the property sector, in the coming year.
In a separate survey by another property agency, 78 per cent of 906 respondents said the government should take measures to curb property prices as soon as possible.
